steps.title: Harvest bay leaves from plants that are at least 2 years old.
steps.content: Harvest bay leaves from plants that are at least 2 years old. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Pick leaves during the middle of summer.
steps.content: Pick leaves during the middle of summer. The midsummer season allows bay leaves to produce their oils more abundantly, making harvesting easier.

steps.title: Take the bay leaves off the trees in the morning, after the dew has evaporated.
steps.content: Take the bay leaves off the trees in the morning, after the dew has evaporated. This will ensure your leaves do not wilt. Detach the bay leaves gently from the trees. You do not want to bruise them. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Choose leaves that are healthy and undamaged.
steps.content: Choose leaves that are healthy and undamaged. You should pick the largest leaves that are available, as these will have the strongest flavor and fragrance.

steps.title: Rinse the bay leaves under a cool, gentle stream of water.
steps.content: Rinse the bay leaves under a cool, gentle stream of water. Shake off the water and pat them with a paper towel to dry.

steps.title: Place paper towels on a baking sheet.
steps.content: Place paper towels on a baking sheet. Make sure you have enough paper towels to cover the sheet, but you do not need more than a single layer.

steps.title: Spread the bay leaves onto the paper towels.
steps.content: Spread the bay leaves onto the paper towels. Do not put leaves on top of one another; they should be separate and have their own space.

steps.title: Leave the bay leaves in a warm, dry room that has plenty of ventilation.
steps.content: Leave the bay leaves in a warm, dry room that has plenty of ventilation. They should not be in direct light of any kind.

steps.title: Allow the leaves to dry for 2 weeks.
steps.content: Allow the leaves to dry for 2 weeks. You can flip them once during the 2 week period to ensure each side dries evenly.

steps.title: Notice whether there is any remaining moisture left in the leaves.
steps.content: Notice whether there is any remaining moisture left in the leaves. If they are still dark green in spots or soft, they may need 1 more week to dry.

steps.title: Pre-heat your dehydrator to 95 to 115 degrees Fahrenheit (35 to 46 degrees Celsius).
steps.content: Pre-heat your dehydrator to 95 to 115 degrees Fahrenheit (35 to 46 degrees Celsius). [3] X Research source Set the heat level higher depending on the area you live in. Places with high humidity, such as Florida, will need a higher dehydrator setting.

steps.title: Rinse the bay leaves under a cool, gentle stream of water.
steps.content: Rinse the bay leaves under a cool, gentle stream of water. Shake off the water and pat them with a paper towel to dry.

steps.title: Arrange the herbs on dehydrator trays, in a single layer.
steps.content: Arrange the herbs on dehydrator trays, in a single layer. Place the trays in the dehydrator and allow them to dry for 1 to 4 hours. steps.title: Check the instruction booklet that came with your dehydrator for any other instructions.
steps.content: Check the instruction booklet that came with your dehydrator for any other instructions.

steps.title: Check the bay leaves periodically.
steps.content: Check the bay leaves periodically. You will know they have completed drying when they begin to curl or crumble and the stems start to split.
